The conversations shared during the creation of this work supported each participant in contribute their voice to an ongoing dialogue of contemporary Australian identity and how we define ourselves as a diverse, interconnected nation both now and into the future.
Title: Participatory Community Embroidery

Description:
Participatory Community Embroidery, Untitled (flag) takes the form of a handmade Australian flag, adorned with a range of motifs (a shooting star, gay pride stripes, flowers) that have been stitched by many different people who come together through workshops organised by the artist. There is a liberating aspect to this communal process, Benson says, for new arrivals to Australia who bring with them a profound sense of culture and identity. Reflecting on notions of nationhood, participants in Benson’s project are invited to decide ‘what to change and what to keep’ in relation to the Australian flag, and to personalise their relationship to it. The idea of graffitiing onto the flag – but with beads and sequins – is also explored through Benson’s work. He says: ‘it represents an open conversation about what the flag, and being Australian, means to each of us – and most importantly, that we are all joint authors of the statement.’ It is suspended from a flag pole attached to the gallery wall, extending outwards into space and visible in three dimensions.

Originally working with performance and its documentation through photography and film, Benson has turned to embroidery itself for his most recent works, often engaging other individuals and groups in their realisation. For the first decade of his practice, he recalls, he sought to unpack his own identity as a queer, white male living in Western Sydney. In the second decade, he has moved towards a wider exploration of cultural identity – of ‘who we are’ – as individuals and a nation living in the present. Through the works, he concludes, ‘different cultures and subcultures speak to one another, as an act of solidarity’.
Title: Participatory Community Embroidery

Description:
The five panels of Particle paradise (nuclear family) are painted in earthy tones of umber, ochre, grey and black. This purely abstract work is built up from layers of painted shapes and marks, each carefully applied to provide an underlying order to the work’s apparent randomness. Uniform circular shapes appear in regular lines, interspersed with explosive spirals and gestural marks, intersected at intervals by cascading diagonals. Like staring into the night sky, with its shooting stars, patterns of constellations and intimations of infinity, Particle paradise (nuclear family) is a meditation on the big questions of existence: of time, matter, space and our place within the cosmos.

The febrile energy of Particle paradise (nuclear family) suggests the constant movement of matter in which cells divide and atoms collide, whether within the realms of our own bodies or at the outer reaches of the galaxy. For Brian Blanchflower, painting involves merging inner experience with reactions to outer phenomena. It is about opening oneself to the unknown. This work is a meditation not only on the idea of matter but on the very materiality of painting. The tinted weave of the underlying canvas can be glimpsed between thick encrustations of paint, some of which incorporate the very matter of earth itself – lint and sand. The painting thus works as much on a tactile level as it does a visual one, creating a surface tension between two- and three-dimensionality that suggests the interweaving of the physical and metaphysical in our musings upon the nature of the universe and the state of being. The notion of infinite “magical transformations of worlds within worlds” continues to fascinate the artist.
Title: Particle Paradise

Description:
The Strobe Series is an exploration of Marion Borgelt’s fascination with the behaviour of light. The works in this series are large-scale abstract paintings referencing waves of bending, twisting light. Their lurid, pulsing bands of colour are combined with nuanced, delicate shades to create a dynamic interplay with surprising optical effects. The extremes of contrast and colour play in the works are at times unsettling as the intensely coloured paintings pulse with light, phosphorescence and kinetic energy. Using strong palettes of red, white and black – or purple, yellow and black offset with bands of green, pink or white – Borgelt creates resonating waves of colour across the canvas surface.

The Strobe Series revisits Borgelt’s exploration of optical effects seen in her earlier Liquid Light series of paintings, here expressed differently and in a bolder painterly way. Her interest in colour has developed in new directions in these works, including the illusionary effects of subtle bending and layering alongside bolder, jarring and unusual colour combinations, resulting in works that are seductive and alluring with a sense of both darkness and energetic vibrancy. For Borgelt, the shrill colours reflected “a new way of bringing life into my work, getting it to radiate and become active on an optical level. It’s bittersweet … I like to hit that point at the edge of bad taste and still get it to work.”1 Borgelt has carefully blended the edges of the bands of colour with wide brushes so that they look almost airbrushed. Some bands are translucent, some are solid, some shift fugitively, others sharply, creating optical effects that are like the insistent pulse of music.
Title: Strobe Series

Description:
These seven objects are from a larger ongoing body of work begun in 2015 titled One Hundred Vessels. The series will eventually comprise exactly what its title describes: 100 cast-metal vessels. The series stems from Matthew Bradley’s interest in fire and heat as transformative forces, coupled with his questioning of what constitutes vital, fundamental human knowledge and skill sets. As both archaeology and early/pre-modern history tell us, the developing ability to create objects from metal is central to narratives of human development. With the One Hundred Vessels project, Bradley implicitly poses a what if: What if we had to learn such skills afresh?

To make One Hundred Vessels Bradley researched and built his own metal furnace in his backyard using LPG canisters, and made his own tools with which to work the furnace. He then set himself the task of designing and casting 100 vessels, in part as a process of developing his own knowledge of and skills in metal casting. The scale of each vessel is limited by the size of the furnace, resulting in individual works that have an intimate, handheld quality. Bradley’s designs alter greatly from object to object; some appear to reference specific historical periods, cultures or locations, while others are more elusive – even science-fictional. In their various forms, styles and fabrications – whether rough-hewn or finely finished – the vessels suggest an archive of technological and aesthetic innovation that speaks to the continuing narrative of human development, adaptation and ingenuity. Bradley is fascinated by these processes of invention and making and his works explore the ways in which technological experimentation can open up enquiries into histories of invention, and the potential limits of human knowledge and expansion.
Title: Vessel no.16 from the series One Hundred Vessels

Description:
For the sculpture Randomly – Now and Then, Joan Brassil wired solid rock to electronic components that cause their crystalline structures to vibrate at their resonant frequency. The rock cores, drilled from deep within a mountain, ‘sing’ with their own resonant energy between periods of unexpected silence. The diorite cores hang from microphone stands, sounding at random intervals, connecting lines of sight and sound between object and viewer. Hearing them sound is a reminder of the deep processes of energy transformation from molten lava to igneous rock that formed them. Brassil has noted that “this work is a measure of time, from when the rocks were formed – to one nocturne”.1

The observation of the natural world – of metamorphosis, symbiosis and the transference of energy from one state to another – are the hallmarks of Brassil’s practice. In other works she used oscillators and modulators to create soundscapes from the tones of pulsars, which are the remnants of dead stars. Brassil collaborated with scientists, astronomers, dancers and computer programmers in a number of works, blending scientific enquiry and experimentation with poetry, dance and sculpture. Her installations are poetic explorations of our place in the universe and our relation to time and space, which she suggests is never linear and can never be fully plumbed. The sense of wonder and philosophical curiosity that infuses her practice melds art and science, the tangible and intangible, to make space audible and time visible. Using sound, electronics, gravel and stone, Randomly – Now and Then spans cosmic and terrestrial time, resounding from the ancient geologic upheavals that formed the earth to the present moment ringing in our ears.
Title: Randomly - Now and Then

Description:
Lauren Brincat’s video Hear This depicts the artist alone in her studio during a residency in Berlin, speaking on a telephone to her mother back in Australia. The telephone is made from watermelon wedges that the artist slices and consumes as she speaks, literally eating her own words in a forlorn yet comical representation of homesickness. As the video progresses, the watermelon soaks Brincat’s clothes and dirties her hair and face, creating a disquieting and awkward performance.

Sound plays a significant role in Hear This, as in many of the artist’s works. The soundtrack acts as an emotive device, drawing on both personal and cultural recollections. Unassuming noises such as the cutting of a slice of melon, or a seed falling onto the wooden floor, take on greater importance in the video, emphasising both the solitude of the figure and the intimacy of the performance. Brincat’s other video works often document repetitive actions performed by the artist – walking, eating, talking, rowing a canoe. Acknowledging performance art of the 1970s as an inspiration, Brincat describes her works as pushing “physical and cognitive limits”. Previous works have seen the artist hold onto the edge of a diving platform above a swimming pool for as long as possible, play a drum kit raised metres above the ground, or walk for a distance in a field of fog.

Brincat also frequently uses inanimate objects as totems. Everyday items take on deeper significance to reference wider concepts including personal memories, particular sentiments or emotions, and art-historical events. In Hear This, the watermelon, an expensive luxury brought during a cold winter in Berlin, takes on wider connotations of home, childhood, summer and Australia.
Title: Hear This

Description:
The representation of the world that Louisa Bufardeci creates in Ground Plan is based on the distribution of people world-wide. Each nation is shown relative in size to its population, so Australia, with its proportionally small population, is shown dwarfed by its neighbour, Indonesia, with its much larger population. In a traditional world map, these positions would be reversed and Indonesia’s archipelago of islands would be dwarfed by Australia’s far greater landmass. But even this rendering of what we assume to be a geographical fact is unstable. The Mercator projection of the world, developed in 1569 and widely used ever since, misleadingly makes those countries further from the equator look bigger, and those closer to it, smaller. In this and other works, Bufardeci questions the veracity of our representations of global geography and politics, basing her wall drawings, installations and sculptures on statistical data acquired from UNESCO, national censuses, opinion polls and the CIA World Factbook.

In Ground Plan, Bufardeci pictures global population distribution as a series of rooms in a sprawling complex of buildings, each with its door open. The porous boundaries between each room and its neighbour suggest a free passage between borders that is not always reflected in today’s geo-political landscape. The movement of resources, commodities and people between nations and across borders is under constant surveillance and negotiation, with doors and borders closing or reopening with each new war, refugee crisis, trade pact and peace agreement. Bufardeci’s wall work shows a rendering of quantitative data as an architectural plan rather than a pie chart or column graph or the sorts of diagrams in which statistical information is generally represented. Her mapping of the global relationship between people and the space they inhabit is one that reflects on not only the unequal distribution of population, but, consequently, of wealth, resources and power.
Title: Ground Plan

Description:
The surface of Blue Reflex recalls the glossy paint job on a car, transposed from the aerodynamic curves of a speeding vehicle to the still surface of a painting in a gallery. In his use of automotive paint applied by airbrush to a plywood base, Ian Burn has purposely created an object that betrays no sign of the hand of the artist. Unlike his previous monochrome works of blue acrylic paint on stretched canvas, Blue Reflex eliminates the textured weave of canvas and the grooved strokes of the brush. Its shiny, mirror-like finish reflects the environment around it, and those who view it. Glimpsing themselves in the patina of the high-gloss paint, the viewer momentarily becomes a part of the artwork.

In this use of reflectiveness, Burn expands upon the modernist idea that an artwork should be about the conditions of its own production. Kazimir Malevich manifested this idea when he created the monochrome and non-objective painting, Black Square in 1913. Rather than reflecting an external reality, Malevich’s painting – and the abstract works that followed it – redefined art as an object that could be concerned only with itself, with its own medium and materiality. Blue Reflex continues in this vein of self-analysis and critique, but brings another layer of critical awareness in its use of a polished surface that reflects not only the reality around it but the viewer who views it. In inviting the viewer to reflect upon themselves as they interact with art and the gallery environment, Blue Reflex implicates the viewer in not only the reception but the production of art, making the artwork both an object and an experience. In creating this shift from a perceptual to a conceptual appreciation of the object in Blue Reflex, Burn argues for a critical awareness about what art is, how it can be perceived and what role and function it plays in society.
Title: Blue Relfex

Description:
Bob Burruwal’s three-metre-tall Morning Star Pole is an impressive symbol of the important Marradjirri ceremony of Arnhem Land. Lasting for two to three weeks, the Marradjirri ceremony brings together two groups to strengthen social and economic ties. One group invites the other, who then prepares to perform the ceremony on the lands of the host. Central to the Marradjirri is the morning star pole, which the invited performers construct, decorate and transport. The dancers perform for two to three hours each sunset, their bodies adorned with ochre-painted clan designs that grow increasingly elaborate as the ceremony continues. The morning star pole appears on the final night and the dancers engage with it by working the feathered strings. After its presentation to the host group, the pole is set into the ground while the head song-man chants a list of clan names associated with the travels of the creation ancestors.

 Burruwal’s Morning Star Pole – festooned with cuffs of feathers in orange and black, green and yellow, and a range of white – evokes the grandeur of this ceremony. Three sets of feathered strings animate the pole by suggesting its action during the Marradjirri, while the clustering of feathers speaks to the constellations of the night sky and the bands of tightly bound coloured string the rhythms of song and dance.

 Burruwal is renowned for his fibre and wood creations, and for sculpting ‘willowy, animated depictions’ that can be ‘imagined as spirits gracefully traversing the tropical savannah landscape of the Northern Territory’.[1] The beauty of his morning star pole lies not only in its ceremonial function, but in its combination of distinct textures – kurrajong wood, fibre, ochre and the feathers of local birds. Like all Maningrida artists’ works, Burruwal’s pole uniquely contrasts the ephemeral and permanent, with the fragility of the feathers balancing the strength of the kurrajong.
Title: Morning Star Pole

Description:
The contemplative gentleman and the lofty landscape he surveys in In search of a style recall a painting style that was over one hundred years old when Stephen Bush painted it. The subject and style of the work are typical of nineteenth-century European and American landscapes that depicted the ‘new worlds’ of Australia and America in picturesque vistas that idealised their wildness and beauty. Inspired in part by the literary movement of Romanticism, which sought man’s redemption through exposure to nature and the experience of the sublime, the solo traveller/explorer beholding an awe-inspiring landscape was a popular theme at the time.

The central figure in Bush’s painting appears in the guise of a puffy, buckskin-wearing bourgeois adventurer. Eager to embrace the unknown whilst staking economic and social claims in the name of progress, this pensive man embodies the ambiguity of such personal pursuits. As claimer, conquerer, and civiliser he stands surveying the vast possibilities that Nature affords, while mourning its irrevocable loss. The inherent duality of this civilising impulse, and its historical representation, is sardonically pilloried in Bush’s painting. He elides the artist’s vocation with that of the heroic settler/explorer, who balanced the constant see-saw of boom and bust.

Bush reiterates this style in many of his paintings to work through the legacies of colonialism, particularly in terms of Australian history and identity, but also to tease out the entwinement of history and visual culture. The paintings which both produced colonial history and are a product of it continue to line the walls of Australian galleries, competing for attention against other more recent styles which will one day also uniquely manifest their own historical moment.
Title: New Worlds

Description:
The lure of Paris is an ongoing series of monochrome paintings that replicate the same image – a dramatically rocky seascape in which three stuffed Babar elephants abseil between clifftop and sea level. Each painting in the series is an original, painted from memory, with the same title; each differentiated only by its serial number. The imagery of the painting is a curious collision of serious ‘high art’ Romantic landscape and ‘low art’ popular children’s illustration. The fictional elephant depicted is Babar, a French children’s book character created in 1931 by Jean de Brunhoff. The story of Babar, who leaves the African jungle to be westernised in an unnamed city before returning to rule over his fellow elephants, can be read as a narrative of colonialism. With his natty three-piece suit and penchant for red wine and sculpture, Babar brought a very French form of western civilisation to his herd. Perhaps, as Bush suggests in the title of this work, Babar is also beholden to Paris, the locus of French culture, and its lure of style, order and bourgeois living.

Foreign elements are at work in the image – elephants in European suits, children’s book characters in a Romantic landscape – but Bush reconciles the tension between them by treating the figure of Babar as a realistic element, dramatically lit by the sunlight breaking through a cloudscape. Displaced from the simple line drawings of children’s illustration, as well as from Africa and his ‘pre-civilised’ nature, Babar has fully entered into the rhetoric of colonial imagery as a cultured adventurer taming the wilderness. Bush’s image articulates an odd nostalgia not only for the outdated products of a colonial past, but also for the hard-working nineteenth-century artists who churned out images of well-dressed gentleman explorers in distant lands.
Title: The Lure of Paris

Description:
Christmas Island is from the 2005 series Lapped by Elaine Campaner, which addresses the artist’s feelings about Australia’s border protection policies. Campaner’s photograph of a doll fenced behind cyclone-wire mesh conveys the isolation of Pacific Island internment camps, the anonymity of their holding cells and the plight of the so-called ‘boat people’. The work is a response to the Australian Government’s refusal to allow journalists to photograph or film refugees arriving by boat; as Campaner says: ‘part of my project was to make an historic record via constructed photos, which I thought of as “illegal photos”.’[1]

In this and other works, Campaner constructs the scenes she photographs from everyday, domestic objects – knick-knacks, painted plates, dolls and other toys. The sometimes distant world of public affairs and political issues is thus ‘brought home’ via familiar household things and their theatrical representation of a personal viewpoint. The surprising transformation of these objects in convincing scenarios results in often subversive works that reveal a hidden dimension within everyday materials, a sometimes sinister edge to the throwaway items of material culture.
Title: Christmas Island

Description:
The woven nets of sea stars suspended from the ceiling in Woven Water, Submarine Landscape hang in the air like the ghosts of burst fireworks, a skeletal memorial to an explosive and momentary energy. The dead sea stars that Maria Fernanda Cardosa has used in her installation are found in tropical waters around the world and sold as souvenirs in coastal resorts and towns. Cardosa was living in San Francisco when she made this work, where sea stars sold as mementoes of Fisherman’s Wharf are sourced from as far away as the Phillippines. This kind of intercontinental drift – whether through trade, migration or ocean currents – is familiar to Cardoso, who has lived in South America, North America and Australia. In this work, she presents a congregation of aquatic life forms outside of their natural habitat, dried and bleached in the foreign element of air.

The five arms of the sea stars join to form symmetrical clusters that branch across space in uniform but organic progression.  Their connections form irregular shapes that suggest the constellations of galaxies as they wheel around our planet, or the changing energy of water as it surges and laps at sea and shore. As they twist and furl in their interconnectedness, Cardoso’s sculptures resemble other life forms and phenomena – a spider’s web, a bird’s nest, an insect’s cocoon.  Like bones and fossils, these remnants of living creatures are a kind of memento mori that invites us to reflect on death and its other, life. In its repetitive structure, Woven Water, Submarine Landscape bridges the macrocosm of sky and sea and the microcosm of cellular building blocks that, like the twisting helix of DNA, form the foundations of life.
Title: Woven Water

Description:
The hundreds of dried corncobs that Maria Fernanda Cardoso has threaded on one long thick wire in Corn Cob Coil are vestiges of the fertile soil of Bogota, Colombia, where she was born. Through this choice of materials, Cardoso infuses the visual languages of minimalism and conceptualism with a specific reference to her continent of origin. Now based in Australia, Cardoso’s work explores the natural world and its interdependence with the human world using plant and animal materials in sculptures, installations and videos. Corn has been an important resource for Colombia since it was first domesticated as a crop over 6000 years ago. A staple food across the Americas, corn has a variety of pre-Hispanic mythological associations as well as contemporary connections to region and culture. Today, it is intensively cultivated in genetically-modified form to produce biofuel, and high-fructose corn syrup, the environmental and health impacts of which are now being reassessed.

Cardoso’s sculptural coils of dried corncobs evoke the central importance of corn in everyday pre-Hispanic and Hispanic Colombian life and the diversity of economic and cultural uses to which it can be put. The minimalist simplicity of Corn Cob Coil is enlivened by the varying colours and textures of the multi-coloured Indian corn or Flint corn (Zea mays var. indurate), a variety of corn domesticated before the yellow corn we are familiar with. Stripped of their seeds, the corncobs are the skeletal remains of a life-sustaining crop that speaks directly to the heritage and collective identity of Hispanic Latin America.
Title: Corn Cob Coil

Description:
In On the Origins of Art I-II Maria Fernanda Cardoso explores the art forms of the animal world through the mating rituals of a tiny Australian spider. Her subjects are Maratus, the highly visual eight-eyed jumping spider know by the common name ‘peacock spider’. Like peacocks and birds of paradise, the male Maratus has developed a complex system of courtship display that exhibits its prowess as a dancer, musician and visual artist. Cardoso has recorded their ostentatious mating ritual using HD macro cinematography and a laser vibrometer, capturing their conspicuously colourful dance and the distinctive beat they make with their vibrating abdomens. Unlike a nature documentary’s depiction of species in their natural habitats, Cardoso films the spiders’ rituals against a stark white backdrop, emphasising the aesthetic beauty and the choreographic nature of their courtship.

Projected onto two screens on opposing walls, the male Maratus is seen waving its legs to get the female’s attention. They strut and sway to their own accompaniment – a percussive beat that is amplified as a hyper-real sound with a tactile dimension. The climax of the Maratus’ performance is the unfolding of an abdominal flap that fans out in an iridescent array of colours, like a peacock tail, which you can see more clearly in the two prints that accompany the video. If impressed by the male’s artistry, the female will allow him to approach her. In presenting an art form of performance and display that is not created by, or for, humans, Cardoso argues that humans are not alone in their production and appreciation of the arts. The performing spiders that make these artworks are the product of an evolutionary process of sexual selection that has refined and enhanced their sensory apparatus, creating a discerning aesthetic sense controlled by the females, in which each performance’s aim is to perpetuate life over to the next generation.
Title: On the Origins of Art

Description:
The two figures of Labyrinth chase each other over a cartoon-like maze that is part street map and part children’s boardgame. The simple and highly stylised design employed by Carsley, with its branching pathways, directional arrows and hidden numbers, resembles a snakes and ladders board. The labyrinth traced by the arrows moves multi-directionally from the spot marked ‘you are here’ through a territory of picture book medieval towers to no discernible end point. Overlaid on on this busy map are two cut-out figures caught mid pursuit, frozen in a game of kiss-chasey. Their age and sex indeterminate, they suggest the push and pull of human relationships as they simultaneously flee and embrace each other.

The flattened two-dimensional plane of both the figures and the background in Carsley’s painting are similar in style to those of Keith Haring, whose works were inspired by the street art and graffitti of New York. While Haring’s work is directly identified with its own moment – the 1980s and AIDS activism – Carsley’s Labyrinth looks back to a distant past. The grey toned background is peppered with stylised renditions of  the arches and domes of Romanesque architecture, and its central place finder is marked in Gothic script. Flies, rats, frogs and a deaths-head evoke medieval imagery of plague and pestilence – perhaps as an oblique reference to the scourge of AIDS that struck in the 1980s, sometimes compared to the Black Death that ravaged medieval Europe.

The labyrinth of Greek mythology, where Theseus bested the Minotaur, was a dangerous place of entrapment and confinement, where monsters lurked and only the cleverest escaped unscathed. Carsley’s Labyrinth appears to be a more frivolous game, but at its centre lurks a darker spectre, warning of the dangers inherent in taking the wrong turn or following the wrong path as we chase our desires.
Title: Labrynth

Description:
John Citizen is the pseudonym of the artist Gordon Bennett; it’s a name chosen to suggest Mr Average – the Australian everyman of no stated colour or creed. Working under this name rather than his own allowed Bennett to experiment and indulge in other streams of thought in his multi-disciplinary practice. It served as a counterpoint to Gordon Bennett, his ‘other’, and yet they are one and the same. It also served as a mechanism through which he was able to sidestep some of the challenges of identity politics and the categorisation of his works within the confines of race. When Bennett is labelled an ‘Aboriginal artist’, he is ‘othered’ as an Aborigine and all the preconceptions that that entails. John Citizen lets Bennett take his Australian citizenship and cultural upbringing back from the nether world of the imagined ‘other’. Bennett refused to be stereotyped as an Indigenous artist, which he believed equally misrepresented his Scottish/English parentage. The alter-ego of John Citizen is not a denial of Bennett’s cultural heritage; rather, it is a way of shifting the interpretation of art away from the artist to the artwork itself.

The pop-art-inspired painting Interior (Orange Chair) depicts the kind of minimal, modernist décor found in interior design magazines and ‘lifestyle’ designer catalogues. Canvassing stylish and opulent imagery from the public domain, the work is devoid of detail and shading, and resembles a screenprint in its flat blocks of colour and graphic simplicity. On the feature wall of the room, above a tasteful display of cushions, hangs a painting from one of Bennett’s own series of abstract works. John Citizen thus borrows the work of Bennett and incorporates it into his own; it’s a form of appropriation which shows that Bennett’s painting – whatever its cultural origins – is at home anywhere in the world.
Title: John Citizen

Description:
1992 is comprised of 18 small paintings on canvas boards installed in three rows of six. They feature an organic line that flows across the panels, creating vivid curving forms that switch colour when they cross onto an adjacent board. Clumpy trees feature in some of the panels and their colouration also shifts sharply when intersected by the curving line. The natural forms are clearly secondary and subsumed by the overall aesthetic.

Tony Clark is known for his vivid serialised landscapes that mix and match elements from disparate art historical and design traditions. In 1992 Clark takes the genre of landscape painting and infuses it with decorative design as well as ideas central to late modernism, including abstraction, minimalism and conceptual art. Several of the panels are entirely abstract, devoid of naturalistic features, using a visual language of shape, form, color and line to create a composition. The painting on the lower right is a yellow minimalism monochrome. The form of the work, composed of multiple objects in a series, is aligned to conceptual art in which the concept or idea involved in the work takes precedence over traditional aesthetic and material concerns. However, the psychedelic colours and curving forms are typical of 1960s design in graphics, interiors and fashion.

Waradgerie (Wiradjuri) country in central New South Wales is vast, with hills in the east, river floodplains and grasslands in the interior and mallee to the west. It is known as Three Rivers Country, as the Murrumbidgee, Kalari (Lachlan) and Wambool (Macquarie) rivers course through it, teeming with life. But as the colonial frontier spread west from Bathurst in the early 1800s, the Three Rivers Country was surveyed and cleared, dissected and demarcated, and kilometres of fencing spread through Waradgerie land like cracks through ice.

In her epic installation Three rivers country Lorraine Connelly-Northey wrestles with this history, employing the objects of western industry to map her country. The materials she uses marry the two foundations of her practice: the heritage of her Waradgerie mother and the heritage of her Irish father. While her father encouraged her use of discarded materials, it was as a young child with her mother that she honed her fine handiwork skills through crocheting and sewing. As Connelly-Northey explains: ‘I set out to ensure that however my art developed it would represent my parents equally.’1

In this work the snaking rivers dominate, shifting from rusted rippled iron and the delicate open weave of agricultural fencing to the familiar lacework of rabbit-proof wire. Tying these forms together are coolamons: oval-shaped bowls that form both the riverbanks and the great, cultivated plains of the interior. The work, says Connelly-Northey, ‘pays homage to my mother’s knowledge of water on country … [and represents] the land of the “Waradgerie Winnowers”.’ But it also speaks to her mother’s life experience, ‘born and raised on the banks of freshwater rivers’ in shanties patchworked together with discarded materials like those Connelly-Northey uses in her works of art.
Title: Three Rivers Country

Description:
The title of Timothy Cook’s work Kulama relates directly to the Tiwi initiation ceremony of the same name traditionally performed in the early dry season when the ‘cheeky’ round yam, kulama, is harvested. The circular motif suggests the ceremonial dancing ground, the round fire-pit in which the yams are cooked and the rings that become visible around the full moon at the time of kulama.

For the Tiwi, individual interpretations of Jilamara (design, pattern and colour) remain very personal aesthetic responses to Tiwi culture and the Kulama and Pukumani (funeral) ceremonies. In addition, artists find inspiration in everyday activities such as hunting, fishing and painting. At Jilamara Arts & Crafts Association on Melville Island the artists are bound by close kin relationships in which they support and encourage, as well as challenge, each other’s arts practice.

Along with his community of artistic peers, an early inspiration for Cook were reproductions of Tiwi bark paintings commissioned by the anthropologist Charles Mountford in 1954. Since 1996 Cook has explored the elemental forms of Jilamara and Kulama found in the Tiwi archive with a raw immediacy, developing his own distinctive style of intense dotting, striking blocks of colour and expressive gestural marks. Shifting between magisterial canvases and works on paper such as Kulama, Cook has exploited the full potential of scale in his work along with the textural materiality of natural ochre, a marker of Tiwi country.
Title: Kulama

Description:
Sophie Coombs’ multi-disciplinary artistic practice includes drawing, the production of artist’s books, sculpture and installation.

These intricately drawn works on paper testify to an obsessive, detailed drawing practice, on which the artist works for concentrated periods of time. For Coombs, ‘metaphysical drawing’ is a meditative activity as well as a way of comprehending the imaginary and the material world. Thoughts are reproduced as patterns, and drawing becomes a form of writing, akin to keeping a journal. The link between stream-of-consciousness and the activity of the hand is paramount.

Starting with a blank piece of paper, and using felt and fountain pens, Coombs gradually fills the surface with small conjoined freehand circles that play with difference in line, texture and tone. Working on a drawing over a period of months, Coombs’ composition as she describes it will ‘unfold’. The immersive process is the key rather than the pursuit of a particular result.
Title: Untitled sc/ab/102/2001, 2001

Description:
This intricately drawn work on paper is the result of an obsessive, detailed drawing practice, in which the artist works for concentrated periods of time. For Coombs, ‘metaphysical drawing’ is a meditative activity as well as a way of comprehending the imaginary and the material worlds. Thoughts are reproduced as patterns, and drawing becomes a form of writing, akin to keeping a journal. The link between stream-of-consciousness and the activity of the hand is paramount.

Starting with a blank piece of paper, and using felt-tip and fountain pens, Coombs gradually fills the surface with small conjoined freehand circles that play with difference in line, texture and tone. Working on a drawing over a period of three to six months, Coombs’ composition will, as she describes it, ‘unfold’. The immersive process is the key rather than the pursuit of a particular result. Although Metaphysical Drawing is essentially abstract, the emergent pattern takes on the appearance of a landscape.
Title: Metaphysical Drawing

Description:
Peter Cripps’ Another History for H.B. and R.L. references Austrian artist Herbert Bayer (H.B.) and the Australian scholar Robert Lingard (R.L.). Lingard is a professor of education who, like Cripps, is interested in the speculative nature of culture and ideas. Bayer was an artist who taught for a time at the Bauhaus in Germany during the 1920s and then in the United States where he continued to advocate for artistic pursuits that were integrated into the fabric of a modern industrialised society.

Bayer was well known for his graphic design but also his ground-breaking exhibition displays. In the form of a drawing he proposed a radical viewing experience that encircles the viewer in a fragmented yet enclosed space. Cripps’ work realises Bayer’s drawing into a three-dimensional form with flat panels and the addition of mirrored surfaces that critique the system of viewing objects from the front. By re-creating Bayer’s proposal, Cripps’ work considers the role of history in art and how ideas from the past can travel with people and through time.
Title: Another History for H.B. and R.L

Description:
With its bold but simple composition, startling use of colour and raucous brushwork, Pirate is a classic example of Adam Cullen’s painterly technique and his fascination with the renegades, mavericks and tragic characters on the edges of society. These outsiders often formed the subject matter of his bold and provocative paintings. Raw and expressive in style, these works combine satirical, irreverent humour with relentless honesty to re-examine contemporary society.

Cullen’s pseudo-naïve style and use of offensive or abject materials aligned him with the Sydney grunge movement of the 1990s and established his early reputation. His work is challenging and often aggressive in both its subject matter and execution, addressing social issues such as racism, oppression and corruption. Cullen considered his investigations of the darker side of humanity as honest examinations of his environment, resulting in work that is unforgivingly dystopian, yet with a unique, painterly beauty. In Pirate, Cullen’s depiction of the melancholic romanticised anti-hero, with his downcast blackened eyes, is perhaps evocative of failed endeavours, of an impenetrable inner world, and of the darker sides of the psyche and society.
Title: Pirate

Description:
Aleks Danko describes the face in this painting as that of an idiot. This brainless, disembodied head is a recurring motif in his work, first appearing in Taste in 1988 and again in the installation Taste: the DUH-HEADS in 2013. With its staring eyes and foolish grin it could register any emotion, from surprise to terror to embarrassment. Danko uses it to signify a kind of mindlessness, clustering a number of the vacantly staring faces in his installations to create a sense of a mob mentality; the unthinking and unblinking conformity of the crowd. 

The face itself has an important historical precursor: it is based on a child-like drawing in Plate 1, ‘The sculptors yard’, from the book The Analysis of Beauty (1753) by the English artist William Hogarth. Hogarth’s analysis centred on what he called ‘the line of beauty’ – a serpentine S-shaped curve that created elegance, grace and variety in composition. That line is entirely absent from Hogarth/Danko’s simple red face, originally used by Hogarth to demonstrate the artistic simplicity of a naive style, ‘composed merely of such plain lines as children make’ and displaying ‘the most contemptible meanness that lines can be formed into’.[1]

These kinds of aesthetic judgments and pronunciations on beauty made by satirists like Hogarth are precisely what Danko embraces and employs in his art practice. Danko reprises the simple drawing as a wood and steel sculpture that refers to the history of his own use of the motif, and also to its longer history as an example of the ‘unartistic’, to continually critique any imposed idea of ‘good’, ‘bad’ or constructed taste. The recurrence of this face in Danko’s work is a reminder of the importance of independent thought, outside the bounds of convention and conformity.
Title: Incident-Ambivalence

Description:
The miniature cast aluminium house that tops the steel obelisk in DAY IN DAY OUT (epitaph version) is a recurring motif in Aleks Danko’s work.  In its symmetry and simplicity, in which two windows flank a door centred beneath a gable roof, it is the very archetype of ‘home’.  The idea of home, and its associations with identity, comfort and complacency, is a concept subjected to constant scrutiny in Danko’s work.  As the Australian-born son of immigrants, Danko’s childhood home in Adelaide was an enclave of the Ukrainian traditions and Russian language of his parents. Working at a local rubber factory, Danko’s parents conformed to the great Australian dream of home ownership and a life of stability and security in the suburbs. Danko’s installation of the four framed works surrounding the obelisk in DAY IN DAY OUT (epitaph version) is a deadpan tribute to his father, who caustically described his life as a pensioner in terms of ‘Day in, day out, twenty-four hours closer to death.’

The bleak life-cycle that Danko describes in the framed words Birth, School, Work and Death can apply to all walks of life, not just one lived in the suburbs. But with the child-like bungalow at its centre, Danko draws these life stages within the orbit of the one place – the suburban home. A deep ambivalence thus inhabits this deceptively simple work because, in the Australian cultural imagination, the middle-class suburban home can be either a place of refuge or a place to leave; a source of comforting security or crushing conformity.  DAY IN DAY OUT (epitaph version) could, then, be either a tribute to traditional values or a monument to monotony. In his simple statement of four words, Danko summarises the sameness of everyone’s lives, no matter where or how they are lived, what they achieved or what they aspired to. In encapsulating the predictable passage of any existence, DAY IN DAY OUT (epitaph version) proclaims a liberating resignation to life’s essential structure and its inevitable conclusion.
Title: DAY IN DAY OUT

Description:
Portrait of Bungaree is an example of Juan Davila’s distinctive and dramatic collage paintings from the 1980s and 90s. It features quotations from art history and popular culture, and connects with a history of hybrid modernism in Latin America, where Davila was born.

Bungaree was an Australian Aboriginal man who came from Broken Bay, just to the north of Sydney. He was a familiar figure in early colonial Sydney, who welcomed the newly arrived to his land on Sydney Harbour and acted as a mediator between the European and Indigenous communities. Bungaree accompanied Matthew Flinders during his circumnavigation of Australia, from 1801 to 1803, playing a key role in the survey’s success as interpreter and negotiator with Indigenous groups along the coast.

In Portrait of Bungaree, Davila uses multiple and fragmented references to question the hierarchies applied to images and cultural material, challenging the dominance of European and American art from the perspective of Chile (Davila’s birthplace) and Australia, where he later lived. For many years Davila has brought to high art the visual language of the street: tarot cards, comic strips, pornography, political cartoons and cheap souvenirs. His subjects are often people of ambiguous gender, mixed race or, as is the case with Bungaree, marginalised social status. In Portrait of Bungaree and other works Davila questions public attitudes to identity and sexuality, presenting incisive analyses of what he views as the complacency, monotony and questionable ethics of much contemporary culture.
Title: PORTRAIT OF BUNGAREE

Description:
Moving Collected Ambience is a sound work designed specifically to respond to the collection, galleries and new building of the MCA, Sydney. The work was commissioned by the Performance Space and the MCA as part of the Sonic Social performance season and premiered on the 14th and 15th of June 2014 throughout the level two galleries of the MCA. It was created and directed by Julian Day and Luke Jaaniste as part of their ongoing project Super Critical Mass. 

For this performance-installation a large and diverse group of volunteer participants are brought together to create a field of simple vocal sounds for the duration of one hour. There is no set number of vocalists but generally it includes between 50–100 individuals who are following memorised instructions. Their vocalisations vary between open or closed mouths, high or low notes, individually sung or in unison, depending on the proximity to other singers and also to the artworks. They move throughout the gallery spaces, gathering in specific rooms over this time, moving individually or clustering in groups of two or three. The participants are virtually indistinguishable from other members of the public and adopt the meandering route and unfocused, yet constantly refocusing, gaze typical of gallery visitors.

Super Critical Mass deals with the nature of community building and how groups of unrelated people move towards a common consensus despite their differing identities. Moving Collected Ambience creates a temporary and intangible experience dealing with the overlap between sound, space and social relations within the MCA galleries.
Title: Moving Collected Ambience

Description:
David Malangi Daymirringu learnt to paint by watching his elders prepare for ceremony, later beginning his art practice at the mission on Milingimbi Island off the coast of Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory in the 1950s. The funeral of Gurrmirringu, as depicted in this bark painting, became his signature subject, one he would return to and experiment with, focusing on different aspects and perspectives.

The story of the great ancestral hunter Gurrmirringu is related to a place called Mulanga in Manharrngu country in Central Arnhem Land. On returning home after a successful hunt, Gurrmirringu rested under wurrumbula, the white berry bush, but an evil spirit disguised as dharpa, the king brown snake, was hiding in the tree roots. The snake bit and poisoned Gurrmirringu and, as he was the first man, his death brought forth the Marnharrngu clan’s first mortuary rites.

Malangi was born into the small clan group of Manharrngu, the people of the mangrove. Through his father he inherited the Dhuwa moiety lands of Mulanga and Nurrunyuwa on the eastern bank of the Glyde River, and Dhamala and Dhabila on the western side of the river, and through his mother the Yirritja moiety lands further west near Yathalamarra billabong.

Framing the central scene of Malangi’s bark painting is the wurrumbula in flower. As a formal structure these trees divide the painting, the symmetry honouring the highly ordered structure of the ancestral narrative and funerary ceremony to which it is linked. In the shadow of the trees’ boughs lies Gurrmirringu’s body as he is prepared for burial, the crosshatched designs on his torso representing his clan. Surrounding figures play the clap sticks and didjeridu, while the animals and triangular sections of wallaby meat signify both the spoils of Gurrmirringu’s hunt and the mortuary fest.
Title: Mortuary rites for Gurrmirringu the great ancestral hunter

Description:
Mickey Mouse, the archetypal figure of white American consumer culture, appears to have left ‘The Happiest Place on Earth’ and taken up residence in the body of an Aboriginal Australian man, dressed as a woman, in Destiny Deacon’s Where’s Mickey? In a childish game of dress-ups with white gloves, fake ears and a 1950s hat, Deacon parodies the Mouseketeers – the happy, smiling, white children of Disneyland and the television show The Mickey Mouse Club. This program was broadcast internationally in the late-1950s, a period in history that particularly interests Deacon as it pre-dates the many changes to social, race and family relations of the civil rights movements of the 1960s.

Importantly for Deacon, the Mouseketeers presented an idealised, sanitised version of what American children should be like. By presenting a black Mouseketeer in this satirical ‘lo-tech’ dress-up, Deacon highlights the exclusion of non-white people from mass media and corrects this historical discrimination. By presenting a man dressed as a woman, an adult playing a child’s game, Deacon’s comedy further unsettles the binary distinctions which have shaped western culture and its constructions of race and gender.
Title: Where's Mickey?

Description:
Frances Djulibing’s installation of suspended feathers reimagines a landscape of trees and birds and a narrative of star and sky in the form of a mobile sculpture. Djulibing is a Yolngu woman from Arnhem Land in Northern Australia. The manufacture of fibre and cordage from trees and grasses is an important cultural activity in Arnhem Land, and Djulibing continues to innovate within these practices, using the traditional weaving techniques taught by her mother, Nancy Muwalpindi. For Yukuwa, Djulibing has spun twine from the bark of the banyan tree, a native fig that grows by sending down aerial roots. Banyan trees (ficus virens) are not ‘planted’ in the ground, but deposited in the branches and stems of other trees by birds who have eaten the banyan seed. Like the cascading white cockatoo feathers in Yukuwa, banyan roots want to be tethered to the earth.

The inner bark from the banyan’s aerial roots is pounded, peeled, dried and rolled into a light-brown string that can be used for many purposes, such as fixing spearheads to shafts, for fishing lines, bags and baskets. Sometimes red earth is mixed into the fibre, prior to spinning, to make a decorative coloured twine used for arm bands and body decoration.

The feathered strings of Yukuwa are similar to the pul pul decorations that hang from the morning star poles made by artists from Elcho Island. The downy tufts on the tips of some morning star poles represent Venus, the brightest star in the night sky, which is said to be hidden by an old woman in a special feathered bag during the day, and released – tethered to a string – during the night. Yukuwa reinterprets these cultural reference points in a kinetic installation of feather and string, spun from the very roots and wings of Country.
Title: Yukuwa

Description:
Untitled (for Mary Webb) is more than a carpet. It is a woven floorwork that pays homage to a painting by Mary Webb, an Australian artist who bridged the art worlds of Sydney and Paris in the post-war years. ADS Donaldson’s colourful hard-edged design is based on a black-and-white reproduction of an abstract painting by Webb. Although she was a notable mid-century avant-gardist and pioneering collage artist, little is known of Webb today. As he has done for other expatriate abstract artists whose work has been overlooked, such as JW Power and Gerald Ryan, Donaldson reprises Webb’s work in a woven reimagining that shifts the work from wall to floor, and from canvas to wool.

Donaldson’s practice as a painter and sculptor has had a long-standing concern with colour and abstraction. His series of Oranges, Purples and Greens address the trans-global nature of abstraction, conceptualism and minimalism. In devising visual languages which transcended time and place these styles overrode historical and cultural specificity, enabling art that was not tethered to national identity. Artists like Mary Webb, who introduced Australian painters to the international art scene during her post-war sojourn in Paris, were instrumental in linking art practice in Australia to this modern global perspective.

In translating Webb’s work to a woven floorpiece, Donaldson engages with the experimental materiality of mid-century practice, in which artists from the Bauhaus onwards worked with textiles, weavings and fabrics to democratise art, making it mass-producible and available for everyday life. In referencing this other trajectory of modernism, Donaldson navigates the spurious yet problematic split between art and craft that has dogged art history and marginalised craft practitioners, who were often women. Untitled (for Mary Webb) is, then, more than a carpet. It is a lesson in what gets overlooked in the broad sweep of history, and how the retrieval of forgotten fragments can make us think twice and look again.
Title: Untitled (for Mary Webb)

Description:
These six steel panels, painted with words and images describing life within the Titjikala community in the Simpson Desert, have been reclaimed by Heather Douglas from an old water tank that once stood on Maryvale cattle station. The panels are weathered and stained by the artesian waters deep below the surface of the desert earth, marking them with rich earthy ochres. Maryvale cattle station became a gathering place for the Titjikala community and southern Arrernte families in the 1940s, when they gravitated to the station to work as stockmen and domestic helpers. In these panels, Douglas remembers and records the past history and activities of the community.

This old bore-water tank, and others like it, was an important cultural and historical marker for the Titjikala community – especially the women – who lived on the Maryvale station. Women would walk great distances to collect water to carry back to the camp for everyone’s use. The creeks and tributaries that fed the wells and tanks were old gathering and playgrounds, where women would wash clothes in preparation for Sunday church while children played in the creek bed. Douglas has depicted activities such as these on the panels, recalling the ‘old times’ when there was no running water system feeding the camp. Douglas was raised in the community by her aunties, and her grandfather’s initials are engraved on the surface of one of the water tank panels. Many community members recall the sinking of the wells and the activities of station work and leisure that centred on the water they provided – washing, cleaning, swimming and yarning. In reclaiming the panels, Douglas reclaims the shared histories and stories of life on the station, and records the memories of her community.
Title: Irititja Tjuta 1

Description:
In his four-panel painting, 1919, Richard Dunn weaves together two different forms of political expression, both of which speak of the radical changes to the political and social order caused by the 1917 Russian revolution. The four panels of the work appear to be painted in two distinctive styles which when intersected form a cross. The horizontal section is a black and white rendering of a 1919 newspaper illustration, while the vertical is a copy of a 1915 painting by the Russian Suprematist artist, Kazimir Malevich. Each image is taken from a printed source and this is their commonality.

 The geometric shapes and strong colours of Malevich’s painting, Supremus #50 (1915), were part of a new language of art, developed at the turn of the twentieth century in tandem with a wider disruption of the political and cultural order in Europe. Suprematism, the movement pioneered by Malevich, was a reaction against realism and conservative 19th century representation in painting – of the ‘old order’ – and an articulation of an entirely new approach to art and politics that rejected tradition. The radical abstraction of Suprematism coincided with the radicalisation of politics in Europe in the first two decades of the twentieth century, which culminated in socialist uprisings and the Bolshevik revolution of 1917.

 Layered across Dunn’s copy of Malevich’s art political statement is a social political representation, drawn from a 1919 Brisbane newspaper illustration.  It depicts the physical clash of political ideologies in the streets of Brisbane, when 8,000 returned AIF soldiers fought trade unionists and socialists at ‘Russia Hall’ in March 1919.  The violent confrontation, known as ‘The Red Flag Riot’ because of the outlawed red flags and banners carried by the trade unionists, was caused by heightened fear of Russian emigrés - what are now called ‘refugees’ - seen to be aligned with the Russian Revolution, and associated with communism, worker unrest and the fear of revolution. Dunn’s layering of these two representations of political events, occurring on different sides of the world, shows how global politics were manifest locally, and differently; from Malevich’s radical aesthetic expression in Petrograd to the journalistic representation of right wing riots in Brisbane four years later.

Mikala Dwyer made these monochromes painted in nail polish for the 1995 Istanbul Biennale. A number of them were shown as part of the installation Woops (1994), a corner assemblage of suspended lame, strewn satin and stretched pantyhose that crossed a ‘bad’ teenage girl’s bedroom with a burlesque drag queen’s dressing room. Amongst the collection of hung and wrapped objects in the installation was a table of colourful nail polishes; the walls were hung with small canvases painted in their pearly hues. These monochromes acted as a mock minimalist counterpoint to the showy excess of the installation; discreetly standing back and paying homage to the idea of art as paintings on a wall, yet conversing with the ribald installation through their shared language of lurid bodily adornment. The paintings were also the only purchasable, and therefore collectible, part of the installation.

Dwyer has incorporated elements of the feminine masquerade in a number of her works, working with fabrics and accessories strongly associated with dressing up and adornment, such as organza, pantyhose and makeup. Through these materials she conjures associations with the body, with a particular kind of feminine identity and with the rites of passage that create that identity. In No, not ever, the range of nail polish colours in the titles is a reminder of the pleasures of choice in creating an identity, in expressing a social persona, and of accessorising an outfit. The nail polish paintings create an empathy between artist and viewer, a sharing of experience about what it is to create a work of art – whether it be a painting on a wall, or (always a work in progress), ourselves.
Title: No, not ever

Description:
Tango is a wall painting by Helen Eager created specifically for the staircase leading from the MCA’s quayside entry to level one. The work is visible from within the building but also from without and was commissioned by the MCA in 2003 for the reopening of the newly constructed galleries and public spaces. Extending approximately 15 metres in length and seven metres at its highest point, the result is an arrangement of equilateral triangles in bright orange hues that cascades down the stairs towards the light-drenched entrance.  

The triangular forms appear to interact and dance and the painting is filled with movement. The colours are affected by light, and shift and change throughout the course of a day. Eager observes that the title is a respectful tribute to Dance (1910) by Henri Matisse and to Piet Mondrian’s Broadway Boogie Woogie (1942–43) where colour and form dance together. Tango is Eager’s largest work to date and she cites Sol LeWitt as an influence, along with Agnes Martin, Ellsworth Kelly and Bridget Riley. Like the wall drawings of LeWitt, Tango came with detailed instructions so that it can be re-created at a later date.

Eager intended for the work to be joyous and uplifting. The three shades of orange were inspired by masses of nasturtiums in her garden.[1] She describes orange as a ‘gregarious’ colour and chose it for energy in the entrance foyer, and as a foil for the blues and greens of the harbour outside.
Title: Tango

Description:
Each print in Emily Floyd’s series It’s Time (again) graphically represents the words of Australian politicians, writers and actors of the 1970s – a decade that was a turning point in Australian society. In her previous sculptural work, Floyd used text and typographic elements to explore the intersections of design and politics in three dimensions. In this, her first major printmaking project, Floyd returns words and text to paper to highlight the shared utopian ideals and experimental nature of the period.

The series of nine aquatints, which was completed under a fellowship with the Australian Print Workshop, reinvigorates the left wing and alternative tradition of radical printmaking in Australia, which peaked in the late 1970s and early 80s.

It’s Time (Again) quotes the seminal ‘It’s Time’ election speech by the opposition leader Gough Whitlam, who became Prime Minister in 1972. Floyd turns Whitlam’s words into a concrete poem of concentric circles of text, like the groove lines of a vinyl record. Replayed as a poster, Floyd suggests their message is still worth hearing. Other works in the series, such as A Little Community, condense the words of feminist and academic Germaine Greer, sculpting excerpts from her landmark book, The Female Eunuch, (1970) into the shape of the female Venus symbol. In A bird like that never dies, the words of Indigenous actor David Gulpilill from the 1976 movie Storm Boy are formatted in the design of the Aboriginal flag, designed in 1971.

In her depiction of these groundbreaking and formative texts, Floyd revisits a specific political history of activism and dissent, when left-wing policies, the feminist movement and the fight for aboriginal rights fundamentally reoriented Australian society and culture.
Title: It's time (again)

Description:
These striking screen-prints are a pithy visual summary of almost a century of feminist campaigning in Australia. In the first, late nineteenth-century suffragists pose in the act of making agitational graffiti: ‘Votes for Women’. Their sober dress contrasts nicely with the incitation to political change. The second image, from 1977, shows Sydney feminists recreating the suffragists’ pose, this time calling for participation in a Women’s March for Liberation. Toni Robertson’s use of photographs in her prints underscores her commitment to historical knowledge, as well as to political change. In both cases these are actual women: the earlier struggles for women’s suffrage, and later for equal rights, were real and urgent.

The continuities between the two periods are crucial:  feminist historian Anne Summers unearthed the earlier photograph in the 1970s, while researching Australian feminism, and today Robertson remembers these discoveries were precious evidence of Australian women’s history of commitment and achievement. While both photographs were staged, Robertson interpreted them differently through the multiple colours and layers of printing ink: the suffragists are pictured with a black and sepia palette speaking to times past, while the 1970s is seen through delicate greys suggesting straightforward documentary. What links the two images across the century is the boldly written red text across the bottom of each, clearly handmade, entirely passionate.

Toni Robertson came to screen-printing while studying art history at the University of Sydney, seeing posters and prints as tools for feminism. Importantly, she participated in the 1973 strike prompted by the refusal of the University’s Philosophy Department to introduce a course on ‘Philosophical aspects of feminist thought’. The University eventually bowed to student and staff pressure, and the course was introduced from 1974. Toni Robertson continued her distinguished work with political postering and printmaking for another decade.
Title: History I

Description:
Turning with the flow of air, Emily Floyd’s suspended Garden Sculpture owes its twisted ladder construction to both garden wind decorations and the molecular composition of DNA – the organic code that carries the instructions for life. The tenuous connection between these two otherwise unrelated forms is made concrete when the individual rungs of Floyd’s helix are examined. Each of the Beech rods spiraling out from the centre is inscribed with the URL of a website, blog or do-it-yourself forum used by Floyd as she researched permaculture and environmental activism in Australia. The work functions as a research map of Floyd’s interest in grassroots political movements and the role of collective action, embodying the internet’s role in facilitating self-initiated learning.

Floyd’s previous works have considered the relationship between politics and design, and the relationship between global political movements, such as Marxism, feminism and environmentalism and the local forms and actions they take. Floyd is the daughter and granddaughter of wooden toy makers, and her spare, simple and undecorated construction echoes the educational toys of the Bauhaus and Steiner schools, which sought to improve the lives of children and the role of teachers through good design and an educational philosophy of organic play and unstructured investigation.

In Garden Sculpture Floyd suggests that, like a communal garden, the internet can be a space of collaborative enterprise for a common good. When people come together in online forums and blogs to share a resource, to cultivate an idea or benefit from another’s experience, they contribute to an expanding knowledge base that Floyd sees as an essentially positive force. Each rung in the spiral constitutes a body of information, opinion and action, which together comprise a collective knowledge that, like a garden, will grow, take root and spread or, left untended, will wither and die.
Title: Garden Sculpture

Description:
The three sepia-toned photographs in Fiona Foley’s Badtjala Woman series are based on colonial images of Badtjala people, whose country includes Thoorgine or K’gari (Fraser Island), taken by an ethnographic photographer in around 1899. The images are held in the John Oxley Library in Brisbane, and were used by Foley in an earlier installation, Lost Badtjalas – Severed Hair (1991).

For Badtjala Woman, Foley has replicated the head and shoulders composition of ethnographic photography, which aimed to record its subject not as an individual but a type; a subject whose exotic features and behaviour could be scientifically catalogued. She has also included the woven bag and necklaces that were collected by ethnographers as records of Indigenous material cultures, and which were important products of women’s work.
Nakedness was often demanded by ethnographic photographers, who asked their subjects to undress in order to conform to an idea of what an ‘authentic’ Indigenous person looked like. These images were then sometimes circulated for non-scientific purposes as exotica, in the manner of Paul Gauguin’s island Venuses − a western imagining of the mythical sexuality of ‘black’ women.
Foley critiques the operation of colonial power disseminated through this kind of imagery by taking it over – directing the shoot and posing for the photographs herself. In doing so, she overturns the anonymity and subjugation of the original subjects and aligns herself with them as their descendant, a contemporary Badtjala woman in control of her own identity and image.
Title: Badtjala woman

Description:
Bliss was filmed at an opium farm in Tasmania, the camera slowly panning across an endless field of silvery, shimmering poppies gently moving in the breeze. The quietly contemplative framing is interspersed with text from the 1897 Aboriginals Protection and Restriction of the Sale of Opium Act. This legislation, enacted by the Queensland Parliament, had two main aims – to criminalise the supply of opium to Aboriginal people (the principal purveyors of which were considered to be Chinese traders), and to ‘protect’ Aboriginal people from substance addiction by forcing them onto reserves under the guardianship of government-appointed Protectors of Aborigines. The Act controlled the lives of Aboriginal people by significantly restricting their autonomy and freedom to live, work and marry as they chose, and worsened the already troubled relations between white, Asian and Indigenous peoples in Queensland. Fiona Foley has used the 1897 Act and its impact in a number of works, of which Bliss is one.

A sense of opium’s hypnotic effects is suggested by the rustling sounds and movement of poppy heads swaying on their stems, interspersed with short quotes from Dr Rosalind Kidd’s 1997 book The Way We Civilise: Aboriginal Affairs – The Untold Story. This forensic archival study examines the disastrous consequences of benevolently intentioned projects that sought to ‘reform’ Indigenous Australians from 1897 to 1981. Bliss’s vivid and dynamic footage of Tasmanian poppies grown for medical purposes provokes contemplation on the nature of the ‘fix’ that addictive substances offer to individual and social conflicts.
Title: Bliss

Description:
In The Door Was Open… a ball of ice gradually encrusts a chandelier, its glacial encroachment threatening to short out its branching filaments of light. The crystalline structure of the ice is mimicked in the cut-glass lustres which hang from it like icicles, making the graft between chandelier and freezer seem perfectly natural – two domestic appliances ‘at home’ with one another.

Powered by both electricity and a concealed refrigeration unit, The Door Was Open… is a poetic musing on humanity’s conflicted relationship to nature and natural forces and resources. Our dependence on electric lights, fridges and air-conditioners moderate our environments to make them more livable, even as their carbon emissions change weather patterns and make them more indispensible. In a reverse of global warming, it is the advance, rather than the retreat, of ice which will here engulf the fitting and short the lights. Glacial growth rather than melt threatens the existence of this chandelier, but the heat of the lights promises an effective check on the enveloping ice, suggesting that in this pairing of the elements there is at least a self-perpetuating equilibrium. Whether the ice grows on the chandelier like a parasite, or the chandelier grows out of the ice like a vine from its host, there is an intimation here of a beautiful and finely calibrated ecosystem hanging in the balance between the natural and the manmade.
Title: The Door Was Open

Description:
A Wiradjuri woman from central-western NSW, Nicole Foreshew explores the relationship between the body and the earth in artworks that consider concepts of time, materiality, growth and renewal. Country and culture play a significant role across the artist’s multi-disciplinary practice, which encompasses photography, sculpture, textiles and video. The artist draws on personal, familial and cultural relations to place, referencing the deep connection that has developed between people and the environment over generations. Working with processes of observation, listening and enacting, Foreshew documents the transformation of the land or creates situations in which the subtle, often invisible, actions of the earth are made visible.  

Recently the artist has created a series of ephemeral artworks that ‘awaken places of memory beyond the temporality of ruins’.[1] Working primarily with installation, sculpture and performance at sites of personal, familial and cultural significance, Foreshew then records these temporal actions using a range of mediums including photography and video. In works such as Cultural Drift (2016), Foreshew reflects on her relationship with Country and ‘its associated histories, commodities and lifecycles’. 
Cultural Drift is a single-channel video that depicts a large object wrapped in fabric on the shoreline of a secluded beach. A constant breeze ripples the material giving the appearance of a lifeform – emerging and rising, swelling and surging.  Surrounding the swathed object are shallow pools of water that shimmer in the sunlight, while in the distance large wave crashes against the rocks. Sound and colour play a key role in creating a sensory experience of place in the work. The muted sepia colour palette of the video accentuates the textures and forms of the site, highlighting the refined patterns and understated materials of the land. While the accompanying soundtrack weaves together field recordings of seagulls, howling wind and breaking waves alongside an electronic composition. Over the course of the video the sounds of nature morph into an evocative soundscape and back again.
Title: Cultural Drift

Description: In ngayirr (sacred) (2015–17) Foreshew brings together an ‘awareness of place together with cultural knowledge of earth, mineral and plant materials’.[1] ngayirr (sacred) comprises of nine tree limbs found by the artist on Country that have been ceremoniously transformed.  The head or tip of each limb is covered in a crystalline skin that range in colour from pale pink to deep russet.  Installed leaning against the gallery wall, the individual branches evoke bodily forms.  Foreshew intentionally buried the limbs underground in a site of personal significance. Over time a crystalline skin grows across the limb, the result of a chemical reaction deep with the earth. Referencing spiritual and cultural practices of the artist’s homeland, ngayirr (sacred) traces ‘personal connections to kin and the material knowledge required to retrieve and revive the body’
Title: ngayirr (sacred)

Description:
In White Australia we see two holes cut into a tiled, claustrophobic corner of what could be a bathroom, laboratory or clinic. An overlay of droning, discordant sound seeps from the space, creating an atmosphere of industrialised torpor. Every few seconds a white rat scuttles out of a hole and across the space – a hypnotic action repeated over and over by other rats throughout the video’s 23-minute loop. Their repetitious movement is a response to what Hayden Fowler considered to be the dangerously apathetic nature of dominant Australian society during the years of the Howard government (1996–2007). Inspired by the unthinking mass movements of 9 to 5 commuters at a busy train station, the artist presents his rats as creatures caught in a system of power over which they have little control.

Fowler originally trained as a biologist, and his work – for which he builds sets and trains animals himself – investigates our problematic interactions with the natural world. He is interested in the nexus between civilisation and the domestication of animals, focusing on aspects such as interdependency and adaptation. Rats have been the companions of mankind, for good or ill, for millennia. The white rats of the laboratory and the clinical trial have been a mainstay of medical science, allowing us to manipulate nature to overcome disease and extend life spans. The rat has also been a cultural mainstay – a metaphor of individual cleverness and cunning, but also of group compliance, a runner in a rat race of pointless pursuit.
Title: White Australia

Description:
Dale Frank’s work Every time I glance it’s just not me evokes the performance of painting and the process of experiencing the work. Lollypop-pink varnish slides down a mirrored surface in which the viewers can see a distorted image of themself. Frank’s paintings inspire numerous interpretations, from dreamscapes to the enormity of the universe, from the psychology of the inner world to the profundity of vast landscapes and the cosmos. All of these interpretations and more are reflected in the surface of the varnish, in the gooey reflective viscosity of Frank’s artistic vision.

Experimenting with the drip and flow of different paints and varnishes on different surfaces, Frank’s paintings evolve slowly over time. The different reactions of different paints to the linen, cotton, fibreglass or – as in Every time I glance it’s just not me – anodised plexiglass surface, create works that change as they dry. Drips formed by gravity pool and harden while colours wash into one another in layers and stratifications. Although Frank moves paint with calculated precision across the picture plane, his paintings ripple with a visual elasticity and sense of immediacy. Incorporating vivid and startling colour, the paintings are layered with a sense of three-dimensionality that can appear as deep voids of blackness and as translucent veils of sparkling light.
Title: Everytime I Glance

Description:
Using a layered four-colour palette Sally Gabori depicts Makarrki, or King Alfred’s country, on Bentinck Island. A warrior and leader, King Alfred was Gabori’s brother. His site on Bentinck Island, Gabori says, ‘is a very special place … [with] a big river that runs through it … This is where dugong and turtles come on a high tide … making it easy for the men to catch them.’

Although Gabori relocated to Mornington Island in the 1940s, she spent the first few decades of her long life on Bentinck Island, the island of her birth. The largest of the Wellesley Islands in the Gulf of Carpentaria, Bentinck Island is low-lying, with its highest point a 10-metre-tall sandhill. While saltpans mark the interior of the island, casuarinas sprout along its coastal sands and mangroves populate its tidal flats. Further fringing the island is a complex system of stone fish-traps, assembled in rock and mortared over time by oyster shells. With their flat planes of solid colours Gabori’s paintings bring to mind these discrete yet interdependent zones, while the combination of colours speaks to the way in which the artist envisages her interaction with these places.

Gabori resided on Mornington Island for the remainder of her long life, but her connection to Bentinck Island life and culture was innate, and her success as an artist enabled her to return to country.
