Her artworks speak volumes about the enjoyment she received from painting; her works ‘are a celebration of her homeland and illustrate a deep connection to country that has not diminished through physical separation.’[2] Through her use of colour and form, Gabori creates reveries of country, of story, of her memories and family, that are at once joyous and bittersweet.
Title: Makarrki

Description:
Tiger Tiger is a well-known work made from reflective road signs that flash and flare when they catch the light. Cut up and reassembled in a grid, the clear directional language of the original signs is fragmented, the letters are scattered and their meaning incomprehensible. The real meaning of the work lies in the experience of the found, weathered and reconfigured material and the play of light upon it.

Although the letters across the surface of Tiger Tiger do not cohere, language is central to its layered play of meaning. Gascoigne’s early training was in literature rather than the visual arts, and language infuses her work. Her assemblages are frequently referred to as visual poetry and share with modern poetry the construction techniques of fragmentation, repetition and juxtaposition. She often commented that her collaged use of text in works forms a sort of ‘stammering concrete poetry’.

Gascoigne’s titles are always significant and she named this work after English poet William Blake’s 1794 rumination on the beauty and horror of nature, The Tyger. She frequently referred to Tiger Tiger in order to explain how a title would come to her in contemplation, following the completion of a work (see Artist Statement). If the visual effects of Gascoigne’s works are open-ended and experiential, the titles reflect formal qualities that are evocative, personal and precise – providing a point of entry into the work without being prescriptive. Just as Blake’s description of the animal begins, ‘Tyger tyger burning bright’, Gascoigne’s title points to the bold yellow and black colouring and its bright reflection. Similarly, the repetition in the title Tiger Tiger mirrors the two square panels of the diptych and the regular grid evokes the ordered patternation of the animal’s pelt, like Blake’s ‘fearful symmetry’.
Title: Tiger Tiger

Description:
Sky Piece is a work of slow, labour-intensive embroidery in which a patchwork of natural-coloured linen offcuts (left over from canvases used by the artist for her paintings) are joined together by a huge number of imperfect stitches in varying shades of blue. Together, these elements capture the artist’s impression of the vibrant and expansive Western Australian sky. Each palm-sized section of fabric took the artist about an hour to complete, and their variations in hue, stitch-length and direction build up not only a saturation of colour but a map of time – a geography of laborious effort that is at odds with the time-poor, automated society in which it was produced. 

Teelah George stitched Sky Piece while listening to the oral history of an 80-year-old woman, Althea Dorris Barber, outlining her memories of life in Western Australia during the early 20th century. Sky Piece weaves together a kind of women’s history in its interaction with an archive such as this. Although invisible in the piece, the memories of women’s work – of sewing clothes, quilts and curtains – are present in the very nature of George’s own labour. The patched materiality of Sky Piece recalls the ‘waggas’, or handmade blankets, made from old chaff bags by women in rural Australia during the first half of the 20th century. Work like this was often done to the accompaniment of other women’s voices as they talked over the shared task of quilting or patchworking. The sewing bee (still referred to today as a ‘stitch-and-bitch’) was a conduit for stories, wisdom and guidance shared within and between generations, encompassing histories and narratives that have not been recorded or preserved.

Some of these quilts – like the oral history that was the soundtrack to the making of Sky Piece – are now housed in national archives and collections. In Sky Piece George threads the immaterial voice and the material fabric together in an obsessive and repetitive task that speaks to the constant labour of what has been regarded as ‘women’s work’. Using the physicality of the action of stitching and the tangibility of its effects, George creates a work of pure colour that emanates from the materiality of thread and testifies to the work of women in generations past.
Title: Sky Piece

Description:
Matthys Gerber’s Jetmaster (2008) is a classic example of the large-scale abstract Rorschach paintings he has been making since the mid-1990s. Drawing on the inkblot test developed by Swiss psychiatrist Hermann Rorschach in the 1920s, Gerber creates these paintings by pouring paint onto an unstretched canvas, which is then folded in half and then back on itself in various directions to create a multi-coloured abstract ground. He then goes back and paints over sections of the work, modifying and rectifying the imprints created through the initial folding.

Gerber’s evocative titling, along with the use of the Rorschach method to create these works, produce abstract paintings that play with the tensions between the contradictory painting techniques of abstraction and representation. In these paintings, Gerber’s interest in mirroring and the replication of forms is explored, along with the collision of the spontaneous and gestural with the deliberate and stylised. Their horizontal orientation is a deliberate deviation from the conventional presentation of Rorschach tests, which are usually shown on a vertical axis. In this, Gerber was guided by Indigenous paintings, in which the painting’s orientation is proscribed in accordance with the topographical features it represents.

The Rorschach patterning in Jetmaster recalls the decorative design of the fleur-de-lis, which is based on the lily or lotus flower. As a sign and symbol, which is both an abstract pattern and a figurative representation, the fleur-de-lis succinctly illustrates the mirroring and doubling at the heart of Gerber’s painting quest, where the concepts of repetition, speed and variation, as found in music, are mimicked in the folding, opening and painterly aspects of the works.
Title: Jetmaster

Description:
At first glance Matthys Gerber’s Painting for Peter (2003) sits firmly within the tradition of hard edge geometric abstraction. However, as with much of Gerber’s work, there are multiple references at play. The story of Painting for Peter is deeply rooted in the personal – a homage to his friend and fellow artist Peter Tyndall.

Gerber and Tyndall first became acquainted in the mid-1980s when exhibiting at the Sydney gallery Yuill|Crowley. During their ensuing friendship, Tyndall sent Gerber a hand-painted Christmas card featuring Tyndall’s signature square motif, repeated and on the diagonal in black-and-white.[1] Years later, noticing that moisture had affected a corner of the card, Gerber decided to ‘save’ it by colouring it in. The colours he chose came from a remnant of flamboyantly coloured Victorian wallpaper that he found in a derelict house years before. He translated the colours into a repetitive pattern based on Tyndall’s design. Gerber has said of this moment: ‘I liked the association with Peter’s work of creating wallpaper, something I had already done and Peter’s work also suggested.’[2] It was this now collaborative work on paper that Gerber adapted into the large canvas Painting for Peter.

Passed from one artist to the other and back again, evolving with each step, Painting for Peter exemplifies Gerber’s experimental approach to art-making and his willingness to draw from any source, be it high art, the decorative or the domestic.  This re-presentation of other artists’ work, whether subtle or overt, is a feature of Gerber’s oeuvre. In Painting for Peter, he pays homage to the creativity of Tyndall and demonstrates, boldly and playfully, the self-reflexivity and critical importance of art history to his creative process.
Title: Painting for Peter

Description:
This lino print, by the poet, artist and activist Kevin Gilbert, depicts Wiradjuri subjects, stories and heroes. It was made when the artist was in prison from 1965 using the most basic materials: lino taken from the floor and cutting tools fashioned from a used spoon, a fork, gem blades and nails. Gilbert printed the images using the back of a spoon to rub and transfer the ink onto paper. He made a conscious decision to exhibit his prints in a gallery context in 1971, when his artworks were first exhibited at an Australia Council exhibition at the Arts Council gallery. In doing so, these works are widely regarded as being the first by an Aboriginal printmaker.

The first print made in the series is My Father’s Studio, in which Gilbert wanted to show ‘the natural pride and completeness of the Aboriginal artist, the cave, the art, the landscape’. A similar desire informed Corroboree Spirit, which depicts an Aboriginal group who are not only part of the landscape but inseparable from it. Gilbert’s use of his Wiradjuri language in the titles of some of these artworks was a conscious act of cultural affirmation. More generally it provides a deeper understanding and context of not only the Aboriginal experience of artist as historian, social commentator and agitator for change but also forms the basis of the articulate way he has threaded this powerful perspective throughout the development of his poetry, essays, playwriting, photography and award-winning literature. Apart from being the first Aboriginal printmaker, Gilbert was also the first Aboriginal playwright to have his work staged by an all-Aboriginal cast with The Cherry Pickers (1968). Whether through art, literature or political activism, Gilbert aimed to ‘expound on the Aboriginal situation by whatever way, through art or whatever form.
Title: Totality

Description:
The three works of Caress are the traces of typewriters – made by placing sheets of paper over the machines and rubbing them with graphite.  These works are part of a wider series of seven typewriter rubbings made from vintage typewriters that the artist has collected over time – an Olivetti Studio 46, a Lemain Deluxe 850 TR and an Underwood Universal – all superseded by the advent of electric models and then computer technology. The typewriter is a hand-operated machine for making ink notations on paper: an active, and in some hands, expressive tool. Here, Gill has made the machine passive – the marks on paper are of the machine rather than by the machine. The rubbings are like death masks of each typewriter, a final tribute to their passing in the electronic age.

Gill has a diverse art practice, including making photographs, sculptures and collections, and writing and drawing. She is interested in ideas of obsolescence – the archaic idea of the typewriter which has been replaced by the computer today; and the typewritten page itself, which is superseded by current printing technology and liable to literally fade with time. In other works she has documented landscapes and dwellings that are in states of decline and decay.
Title: Caress

Description:
In Tangara, Shaun Gladwell uses the architecture and fittings of a public train as a gymnast uses the rings and bars of a gymnasium. As he grips the rails in a carriage vestibule, Gladwell performs a slow-motion sequence of graceful strength. Outside, the lights of night-dark stations pass by the windows like meteors and comets, as if the train was hurtling through space rather than the suburbs of Sydney. Inside, the fluorescent lighting and hard, glossy surfaces of the Tangara-class train echo the clinical architecture of a space shuttle. Tangara is shot upside-down and in slow motion, creating an inverted and otherworldly effect that turns the train’s vestibule into an anti-gravity chamber, with Gladwell a floating astronaut tethered above the carriage’s central grabrail. The length of his torso and the span of his outstretched arms and legs define the circuit of his choreography within the space, which he moves through without letting hands or feet touch the ground.

Gladwell takes the restless energy of youth, and the urban spaces in which it is exercised, and turns them into a graceful performance of his physicality. In other works, Gladwell has used his skill in skateboarding and parkour to explore and expand upon the ways in which bodies interact with, and express themselves through, their environments. In Tangara, the graceful display of stamina and duration in motion disrupts the conformist behaviours of commuting and the utilitarianism of the train carriage by transforming it into a playground.
Title: Tangara

Description:
Untitled (Interior) II is a bronze casting of a crack that formed in the ground during a long drought. The work is a unique edition from a series of five castings that were made in locations near Nyngan in western New South Wales and Lake George, just outside Canberra. These works were cast in bronze by Apisit Nongbua, a Thai sculptor who works in traditional bronze techniques.

Untitled (Interior) II documents a void that is both ephemeral and in flux. The sculpture suggests something that is invisible or intangible but loaded with a range of shifting meanings – in this case the negative space of a crack in the earth. These cracks, desiccated by drought and preserved in bronze by Gill will, in time, be filled by water, mud and dirt. This idea of the passage of time, of states of transformation and change, are recurring themes in Gill’s work, as is her focus on found or overlooked objects. In Untitled (Interior) II she records a transient state, a symptom of the climate and a rupture in the earth that will continue to change over time as it shifts from dry to wet, infertile to fertile. In other works, using photography and carbon rubbings, Gill has created similar transcriptions of objects and states of being manifesting decline or decay, and the impact of the natural environment on the built world. The bronze cast creates another kind of analogue transcription which makes permanent that which we presume to be in a state of flux. In using a traditional sculptural material such as bronze, and working with a craftsperson whose family has been making bronze Buddhas for temples and the Thai royal family for generations, Gill draws on a range of art historical and cultural references. As Russell Storer writes, ‘Gill’s work takes up a questioning, playful mode that collapses together multiple histories – personal, local and art-historical.
Title: Untitled (interior)
